Article Title: Google 'rejects' ruling that said Google has illegal monopolies in ad technology; says: We won half of this case and we will ...
Article Text:
Google to appeal the ruling

Five big anti-trust cases targeting Apple, Google, Microsoft, Facebook going in the US

Google suffered another legal blow as a judge ruled that the company illegally dominates two markets for online advertising technology. What makes this important is that it paves the way for the US antitrust prosecutors to seek a breakup of Google's ad products. A US judge ruled that Google illegally wielded monopoly power in the online ad technology market, delivering a significant blow to the tech giant‚Äôs revenue engine. According to a report by news agency AFP, district Court Judge Leonie Brinkema found Google built an illegal monopoly over publisher ad servers and ad exchanges, engaging in anticompetitive acts to maintain dominance, harming publishers, competition, and consumers.The federal government and over a dozen US states filed the antitrust suit, accusing Alphabet-owned Google of dominating digital advertising sectors -- publisher ad servers, advertiser tools, and ad exchanges. Brinkema reportedly partially dismissed claims about advertiser tools but agreed Google‚Äôs policies and product feature eliminations entrenched its monopoly.Google vowed to appeal, with vice president of regulatory affairs Lee-Anne Mulholland noting the court found no competitive harm in its advertiser tools or acquisitions like DoubleClick. ‚ÄúWe won half of this case and we will appeal the other half,‚Äù she said, adding that the company disagrees with the decision on its publisher tools. ‚ÄúPublishers have many options and they choose Google because our ad tech tools are simple, affordable and effective.‚ÄùAdvertising accounted for about 75% of Alphabet's $350.02 billion in revenue for 2024. The Google Network business accounted for only 8.7% of the revenue.The ruling is part of a broader US government push to curb Big Tech, with five major antitrust cases targeting tech giants, marking an aggressive shift in enforcement since the Microsoft case in the 1990s.Analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf of Emarketer said the antitrust tide has turned against Google, though legal remedies and timelines depend on appeals, which could span years. The case, launched under the Trump and Biden administrations, follows another ruling last August that Google illegally monopolized search, also under appeal. Online advertising fuels Google‚Äôs fortune, funding free services like Maps, Gmail, and search, and its AI investments.
Article Summary: Judge rules Google illegally dominates two markets for online advertising technology. Paves the way for the US antitrust prosecutors to seek a breakup of Google's ad products. Google vowed to appeal the ruling, with vice president of regulatory affairs Lee-Anne Mulholland noting the court found no competitive harm in its advertiser tools.

Article Title: Google faces potential breakup as judge finds it illegally dominated ad tech markets, company responds
Article Text:
How latest ruling may affect Google‚Äôs business

'We won half of this case...': Google says



In a significant antitrust ruling, a federal judge has determined that Alphabet 's Google illegally dominated two key markets within the online advertising technology sector. The decision, delivered on Thursday (April 17), marks another setback for the tech giant in its ongoing legal battle with the US government.As per a report by news agency Reuters, US District Judge Leonie Brinkema of the Alexandria, Virginia, court ruled that Google unlawfully monopolised the markets for publisher ad servers and ad exchanges, which facilitate transactions between ad buyers and sellers.However, the judge found that antitrust enforcers did not successfully prove Google held a monopoly in advertiser ad networks.This ruling opens the door for prosecutors to pursue remedies that could include the forced breakup of Google's advertising business. The US Department of Justice (DOJ) has previously advocated for Google to divest at least its Google Ad Manager, a suite of tools encompassing the company's publisher ad server and ad exchange.Google now faces the potential of being subjected to divestiture orders or significant changes to its business practices from two separate US courts. A trial is scheduled to commence next week in Washington, DC, where a judge will consider the DOJ's request to compel Google to sell its Chrome browser and implement other measures aimed at curbing its dominance in online search.Prosecutors argued that Google employed classic monopolistic tactics, including acquiring competitors, locking customers into its products, and exerting control over online ad market transactions.Meanwhile, Google's defense argued that the case focused on a past reality, emphasising the company's ongoing efforts to ensure its tools could connect with competitors' products.Previous reports indicated that Google had the possibility of selling off its ad exchange in an attempt to appease European antitrust regulators.Google's legal team further contended that prosecutors disregarded competition from other technology giants, such as Amazon.com and Comcast, and failed to acknowledge the shift in digital ad spending towards platforms like apps and streaming video.Google has responded to the verdict, saying that it will appeal."We won half of this case and we will appeal the other half. The Court found that our advertiser tools and our acquisitions, such as DoubleClick, don‚Äôt harm competition. We disagree with the Court‚Äôs decision regarding our publisher tools. Publishers have many options and they choose Google because our ad tech tools are simple, affordable and effective," Lee-Anne Mulholland, Vice President, Regulatory Affairs.
Article Summary: US District Judge Leonie Brinkema of the Alexandria, Virginia, court ruled that Google unlawfully monopolised the markets for publisher ad servers and ad exchanges. The decision, delivered on Thursday (April 17), marks another setback for the tech giant in its ongoing legal battle with the US government.

In a February 2025 post on X (formerly Twitter), St. Clair publicly acknowledged that Elon Musk was the child‚Äôs father. She appealed to the press to respect their privacy and avoid invasive reporting, noting that the announcement was made reluctantly due to the increasing likelihood of tabloid exposure.she wrote.In late March 2025, the situation escalated publicly when St. Clair appeared in a video published by The Daily Mail, handing over the keys to her Tesla Model S. She claimed that she was selling the vehicle to offset a significant reduction‚Äîapproximately 60%‚Äîin child support payments from Musk.Musk, however, denied the claim that he had reduced support as a form of financial retaliation. Responding to a post by political commentator Laura Loomer on X, Musk stated:This comment contradicts the confirmed paternity test and has raised further questions about the consistency of Musk‚Äôs statements on the issue.Elon Musk is the father of at least 14 children, including Romulus, and has reportedly signed confidentiality and financial agreements with multiple women. Article Title: Bill Gates predicts: Two non-tech jobs once considered 'slowdown-proof' that AI is threatening to take over
Article Text:
Gates cites Nvidia's robots, Keynes' prediction and ...

Bill Gates reportedly has another prediction on artificial intelligence (AI) impacting jobs. Microsoft founder Bill Gates forecasts that artificial intelligence (AI) will soon eliminate shortages of doctors and teachers by filling critical gaps in healthcare and education. According to a report in Business Insider, speaking on the "People by WTF" podcast, Gates said, "AI will come in and provide medical IQ, and there won't be a shortage." He also predicted AI would take over roles like factory workers, construction crews, and hotel cleaners, potentially reducing workweeks and prompting a philosophical rethink about how time is spent. "You can retire early, you can work shorter workweeks," he said, noting even he struggles to adjust to this shift after decades in a world of scarcity.In healthcare, the US reportedly faces a projected shortage of up to 86,000 physicians by 2036, according to the Association of American Medical Colleges. Globally, countries like India and those in Africa also struggle with insufficient medical professionals. AI startups like Suki, Zephyr AI, and Tennr are raising billions to address this by automating tasks like billing and note-taking, improving diagnostics, and identifying patients for new treatments. McKinsey estimates generative AI could add up to $370 billion in productivity to healthcare and pharma.Education faces reportedly similar challenges. According to the report, in 2023, 86% of US K-12 public schools reported hiring difficulties, with 45% understaffed. In the UK, David Game College in London has piloted AI tools like ChatGPT to assist 20 students in subjects like English and math. Educators see AI as a time-saver and learning enhancer, despite concerns about cheating.Gates also highlighted AI‚Äôs potential to revolutionize manual labor. Tech giants like Nvidia are developing humanoid robots for tasks like warehouse picking and floor cleaning, aiming to cut labour costs and boost efficiency. He emphasized that AI‚Äôs ability to replicate physical skills will reshape industries, saying, "The hands have to be awfully good to do those things. We'll achieve that."Reflecting on the future, Gates echoed economist John Maynard Keynes‚Äô 1930 prediction of a 15-hour workweek, noting that despite productivity gains, most still work 40 hours. Gates, who works for enjoyment despite not needing to, sees AI-driven changes as both an opportunity and a challenge to redefine work and leisure.
Article Summary: Bill Gates says artificial intelligence (AI) will soon eliminate shortages of doctors and teachers. He also predicted AI would take over roles like factory workers, construction crews, and hotel cleaners. Gates echoed economist John Maynard Keynes‚Äô 1930 prediction of a 15-hour workweek.

Article Title: Flipkart ends ‚Äòwork from home‚Äô policy, calls employees back to office 5 days a week; says: ‚ÄòBy returning to office ‚Ä¶‚Äô
Article Text:
Amazon, Meesho, Blinkit, and Zepto all have employees working from office

Walmart-owned Flipkart has officially terminated its work-from-home policy, requiring all employees to return to office five days a week. The company, which had allowed remote work since the COVID-19 pandemic began in 2020, is now implementing a full return-to-office mandate across all functions and roles.According to MoneyControl, Flipkart has been gradually scaling back its remote work policy , initially mandating regular office attendance only for senior executives at the vice president level and above. The transition to full-time office work will occur in phases over the coming months, with some exceptions based on job requirements."By returning to office, we aim to foster a strong sense of community for new hires and existing employees; and a shared focus on our common goal," a Flipkart spokesperson stated. The company also confirmed that employees will be allowed a limited number of work-from-home days.Flipkart is among the last major e-commerce companies in India to eliminate remote work options. Competitors including Amazon, Meesho, Blinkit, and Zepto have already implemented five-day in-office policies. Amazon recently mandated all employees return to its Bengaluru office and is relocating from World Trade Centre in Rajajinagar to Devanahalli to accommodate its workforce.Swiggy remains the only major player in the quick commerce space maintaining a hybrid model, with most employees working three days in office and two days remotely, though certain teams work in-office full-time based on job requirements.
Article Summary: Flipkart is among the last major e-commerce companies in India to eliminate remote work options. Amazon, Meesho, Blinkit, and Zepto have already implemented five-day in-office policies. Swiggy remains the only major player in the quick commerce space maintaining a hybrid model.

Article Title: Layoffs or Hiring: America-China Tariff War Sends Indian IT companies in ‚Äòwait-and-watch‚Äô mode
Article Text:
US Tariffs: Hiring slowdown and potential layoffs

Tariff uncertainty and business impact



Indian IT firms are slashing hiring mandates and adopting a cautious approach as the America-China tariff war fuels economic uncertainty. As reported by Economic Times, the $280 billion industry, which heavily relies on North American and European markets, has seen demand for tech talent drop by nearly 20% in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the previous quarter.Recruitment firms report that IT services companies have reduced active hiring demand from 80,000 in February to 55,000 in April. Experts warn that layoffs could follow, particularly in IT services and Global Capability Centers (GCCs), which employ 70% of India‚Äôs tech workforce.Kamal Karanth, co-founder of Xpheno, told Economic Times, ‚ÄúThere is a likelihood of layoffs in the Indian tech industry, especially in IT services and GCCs.‚Äù He added that companies may stop replacing employees, leading to organic headcount reductions.The hiring slowdown follows US President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff announcements, including a 10% minimum tariff on all trade partners and a 245% levy on Chinese imports. While Trump called for a 90-day pause on April 9, the uncertainty has already impacted India‚Äôs top IT firms.Wipro CEO Srini Pallia acknowledged the growing concerns, stating, ‚ÄúThe uncertainties have dramatically increased. We don‚Äôt want to onboard people and then face challenges in deploying them.‚Äù Similarly, TCS CEO K Krithivasan noted that project delays and decision-making slowdowns have emerged since March.Industry leaders expect continued caution in hiring, with firms focusing on backfilling critical roles rather than expanding their workforce. TCS has deferred wage hikes, signaling a conservative approach amid the economic turbulence.
Article Summary: Indian IT firms are slashing hiring mandates and adopting a cautious approach as the America-China tariff war fuels economic uncertainty. The $280 billion industry, which heavily relies on North American and European markets, has seen demand for tech talent drop by nearly 20% in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the previous quarter.

In May 2021, Bill and Melinda Gates publicly announced their divorce after 27 years of marriage, citing irreconcilable differences. The separation marked one of the most financially significant divorces ever recorded, primarily due to the absence of a prenuptial agreement and the couple‚Äôs staggering net worth, which was estimated at $130 billion, according to. The divorce gained global attention not only because of the personalities involved‚ÄîBill Gates, co-founder of Microsoft, and Melinda French Gates, philanthropist and co-founder of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation ‚Äîbut also due to the legal and financial complexities surrounding the equitable distribution of their vast wealth.Despite the magnitude of their combined assets, the couple requested privacy during the proceedings. As a result, many specific terms remain confidential. However, substantial details regarding the properties, artworks, and investments they owned have emerged through public records and credible reports, painting a picture of one of the most high-stakes divorces in modern history.The divorce was filed in Washington, a community property state. Under Washington law, any assets acquired during the course of a marriage are considered jointly owned and must typically be split equally in the event of a divorce‚Äîunless a prenuptial agreement exists. In this case, no prenup was in place. Instead, the couple had signed a separation agreement, the terms of which remain undisclosed but served as the foundation for the division of their assets.Among the most high-profile assets affected by the split was the couple‚Äôs substantial art collection, valued at over $124 million, according to. The collection includes several historically and culturally significant pieces:The Gates divorce also involved the division of real estate worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The properties span several states and serve various purposes, from primary residences to luxury vacation retreats.This high-tech compound on Lake Washington served as the family‚Äôs primary residence and is one of the most iconic private homes in the U.S.Purchased in April 2020, this property contrasts the Gates‚Äô Washington estate with its modern design and beachfront access.This property was purchased in 2014 and may not have been included in the division, depending on how it was categorized under the separation agreement.A luxury desert getaway offering privacy and relaxation, bought by the couple in 1999.Gates' financial portfolio was arguably the most complex aspect of the divorce.Although Bill Gates stepped down from Microsoft‚Äôs board in 2020, he retained significant shares in the company. The exact allocation of these stocks post-divorce has not been disclosed.Founded by Gates, Cascade Investment manages a large portion of his wealth and holds stakes in companies like Four Seasons Hotels, AutoNation, and Canadian National Railway. The ownership structure post-divorce remains private.Despite the divorce, both parties confirmed their continued commitment to co-chairing the Gates Foundation. With over $67 billion in assets, the organization is one of the largest private philanthropic entities in the world. In 2021, a two-year trial period was initiated to evaluate their working relationship. If they found themselves unable to work together after this period, Melinda agreed to step down.
Article Summary: Melinda Gates got mansions, ranches, and a slice of Xanadu 2.0. Bill and Melinda Gates announced their divorce after 27 years of marriage, citing irreconcilable differences. The separation marked one of the most financially significant divorces ever recorded.

Article Title: Starting April 25, China‚Äôs Shein and Temu are losing their Biggest Advantage in the US online shopping market
Article Text:
Impact of Tariff Changes on Shien and Temu

Poll Do you think the price hikes by Shein and Temu will significantly affect your shopping behavior? No, I will still shop there. Yes, I will shop elsewhere.

Shein and Temu‚Äôs response



Popular Chinese e-commerce platforms Shein and Temu are set to lose their competitive edge in the US online shopping market as they prepare to raise prices starting April 25. The move comes in response to new trade policies introduced by former President Donald Trump, including a 145% tariff on Chinese goods and the elimination of a duty-free exemption for low-value imports.The de minimis provision, which allowed goods valued under $800 to enter the US duty-free, will be eliminated on May 2. This exemption had been a cornerstone of Shein and Temu‚Äôs business models, enabling them to offer ultra-low prices on clothing, accessories, and household items. With the new tariffs in place, the platforms will face higher operating costs, forcing them to adjust their pricing strategies.Both companies have issued statements acknowledging the price adjustments, citing ‚Äúrecent changes in global trade rules and tariffs‚Äù as the primary reason. Shein and Temu have also encouraged customers to shop before the price hikes take effect, assuring smooth delivery during the transition period.The tariff changes are expected to impact 4 million low-value parcels arriving in the US daily, many of which originate from China. US retailers, including Amazon, have already begun adapting to the new landscape by introducing low-cost storefronts featuring American brands like Adidas, Levi‚Äôs, and Gap.
Article Summary: Chinese e-commerce platforms Shein and Temu are set to lose their competitive edge in the US online shopping market. The move comes in response to new trade policies introduced by former President Donald Trump. The de minimis provision, which allowed goods valued under $800 to enter the US duty-free, will be eliminated on May 2.

How Elon Musk 'views' fatherhood

A recent Wall Street Journal (WSJ) article has shed light on the personal life of the world's richest man Elon Musk . The article focuses on Tesla and SpaceX CEO's expansive family of at least 14 children with four women. Among the mothers of his children, Shivon Zilis , a top executive at Neuralink , is described as holding a ‚Äúspecial status‚Äù within Musk‚Äôs inner circle, a designation that has sparked intrigue and speculation about her role in his life and family dynamics.Zilis and Musk share twins Strider and Azure (born November 2021), daughter Arcadia (born February 2024), and son Seldon Lycurgus (birth date undisclosed, announced February 2025). Their relationship, which began to draw public attention after the twins‚Äô birth was revealed in 2022, has been described as both professional and deeply personal, though its romantic nature remains ambiguous.According to the WSJ, Zilis enjoys a unique position among the mothers of Musk‚Äôs children, described as a ‚Äúspecial status‚Äù within his sprawling family network. This distinction stems from several factors. Unlike other mothers of Musk‚Äôs children -- such as musician Grimes, author Justine Wilson, or conservative influencer Ashley St. Clair -- Zilis is deeply embedded in Musk‚Äôs professional ecosystem. As a high-ranking executive at Neuralink, she works closely with Musk on cutting-edge AI and neurotechnology projects. This professional alignment gives her a level of access and influence that sets her apart. The WSJ notes that Zilis is seen as a ‚Äústeadying force‚Äù within Musk‚Äôs inner circle, suggesting she plays a stabilizing role in both his personal and business endeavors.Zilis has been increasingly visible alongside Musk at high-profile events, a rarity for someone who has largely stayed out of the spotlight. For instance, she accompanied Musk to a meeting with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Washington, D.C., in February 2025, where they were seen with their children. She also attended Donald Trump‚Äôs pre-inauguration dinner in January 2025, mingling with notable figures like Jeff Bezos and Ivanka Trump. These appearances kind of confirm that Musk may be publicly acknowledging a closer relationship with Zilis, further underscoring her elevated status.The WSJ report suggests Musk has ambitious plans for his children, whom he reportedly refers to as his ‚Äúlegion,‚Äù aiming to raise them in a way that boosts ‚ÄúEarth‚Äôs IQ‚Äù through brilliant minds. Zilis appears to be a key partner in this vision. She has moved into a $35 million compound in Austin, Texas, purchased by Musk to house his children and their mothers in adjoining properties, allowing him to ‚Äúschedule time‚Äù with his youngest kids. While other mothers, like Grimes, have reportedly resisted this arrangement, Zilis‚Äô participation signals her alignment with Musk‚Äôs unconventional family model.Sources cited by People magazine claim that Musk ‚Äúreally loves Shivon,‚Äù suggesting a deep personal bond. Zilis herself has spoken positively about Musk, defending him against critics and praising his commitment to humanity‚Äôs future. In Walter Isaacson‚Äôs biography Elon Musk, Zilis revealed that Musk encouraged her to have children, offering to be her sperm donor because he believed she should pass on her genes. This mutual respect and shared ideological goals -- particularly around AI and population growth‚Äîfurther cement her unique standing.The article, as referenced in The Daily Beast, contrasts Zilis‚Äô status with the experiences of other women in Musk‚Äôs life. For example, Ashley Clair, who claims to be the mother of Musk‚Äôs 13th child, alleged that Musk offered her $15 million and $100,000 monthly payments to keep his paternity secret, an arrangement she says is common among other mothers. Ashley Clair also described Musk‚Äôs demands, such as requiring a cesarean section to maximize brain size, which she rejected. In contrast, Zilis appears to navigate Musk‚Äôs world with less public conflict, suggesting a more harmonious relationship.Musk‚Äôs approach to fatherhood is said to be closely tied to his belief in an ‚Äúunderpopulation crisis,‚Äù a view he has expressed publicly and on X, stating that ‚Äúa collapsing birth rate is the biggest danger civilization faces.‚Äù The WSJ report highlights Musk‚Äôs desire to create a ‚Äúlegion‚Äù of children, strategically selecting women he deems intelligent to bear his offspring. Zilis, with her academic pedigree and AI expertise, fits this mold, and her willingness to have four children with Musk aligns with his pronatalist ideology.The article also describes Musk‚Äôs efforts to manage his complex family through financial agreements and non-disclosure agreements (NDAs). While some mothers, like St. Clair, have pushed back against these arrangements, Zilis‚Äô integration into Musk‚Äôs professional and personal life suggests she operates within his framework more seamlessly, reinforcing her ‚Äúspecial status.‚Äù
Article Summary: Shivon Zilis is described as holding a "special status" within Elon Musk's inner circle. She is deeply embedded in Musk's professional ecosystem, working with him on cutting-edge AI and neurotechnology projects. She has moved into a $35 million compound in Austin, Texas, purchased by Musk to house his children and their mothers in adjoining properties.
